_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE



The Carpenter Co., both Corporate and Lakeland Division, is committed to comply fully with federal , state and local rules and regulations regarding the proper handling ,use, storage and emergency response preparedness to prevent accidental releases of chemicals, toxic or otherwise. Furthermore Carpenter Co. is committed to protecting the health and welfare of its employees, the surrounding community and the environment.  To achieve this goal procedures, policies, preventative maintenance and training is provided. Accidental Release prevention begins with the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, safe handling procedures and checklist used as well as training imparted to our personnel. In addition regular audits and inspections are conducted to ensure our personnel are aware of the safety requirements and implementing proper procedures. 

 The Lakeland Division of Carpenter Co. utilizes an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) based on the requirements of  OSHA's Hazardous Waste and Emergency Response Operations  regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) as well as state and local regulations to manage emergency response activities at the facility. The Contingency Plan for the Lakeland Division includes procedures for proper notification of the local fire department, the police department, and the local hospital, when and if such notification becomes necessary.  The implementation of the ICP at the facility is directly related to the degree of training given to the Carpenter Co. employees in regard to chemical releases and emergencies, fire evacuation and preparation for response to the effect of natural disasters.  The Lakeland Division's attention to Accidental Release Prevention is evidenced by the facility's not having a  release of toluene diisocyanate during the previous fire years.  



2.    FACILITY DESCRIPTION & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, is located at 5150 Fro

ntage Road South in Lakeland, Florida.  The area around the facility is comprised of other industrial plants.  The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, employs approximately 146 full time employees.  The facility manufactures polyurethane foam products for use in carpet cushioning, bedding and furniture applications.  The polyurethane foam manufacturing process utilizes toluene diisocyanate (TDI) [unspecific isomers], CAS# 2647-62-5, as a reactant to produce foam. The Carpenter Co., Lakeland facility has a total TDI storage capacity of approximately 937,716 pounds.  The facility maintains a maximum of three railcars each with approximately 190,000 pounds, one internal TDI storage tank with a capacity of 313,013 pounds, one prepolymer mixing tank with a capacity of 76040 pounds and one prepolymer day tank with a capacity of 27391 pounds. The mixture in the prepolymer mixing tank and day tank consists of 50 percent TDI.  All process tanks are located inside the building within concrete containments. The railcars are located outside the building at the railcar unloading station. The unloading station has stationary drip pans installed to minimize incidental releases. TDI is pumped to the pouring mixing head where it is mixed with other reactants to produce a continuous slab of flexible polyurethane foam. The foam is cut into 100 feet slabs and then stacked in the slab room in order to cure.







3.    WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



Assessment and modeling was conducted for a worse case release scenario of TDI  from The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division  The Worst Case Scenario was assumed to be a rupture of a TDI railcar releasing the entire contents (190,000 lbs) into an undiked area (urban topography).  Using weather data for the Lakeland region obtained from www.wunderground.com, the maximum daily temperature recorded for the past three years was 102?F. The corrected release rate at 102? F (the highest temperature for the last three years in the Lakeland) was 2.3lbs/min

using Equation 3-11  from RMP Guidance for OCA . The estimated duration of release is 82609 minutes using Equation 3-5. The lookup tables in the Society of Plastic Industry's (SPI) RMP for TDI users which is based on the technique described in EPA's RMP Guidance for OCA was used to identify the end point distance. In particular, equation D-1of the guidance document was used to estimate pool evaporation based upon a vapor pressure correlation published by the National Institute of Standards technology (NIST). A Gaussian Plume model was used to determine the endpoint distance based on the evaporation rate. This was found to be 850ft (0.16 miles). Within the area delineated by the endpoint distance there are no residential receptors, however 4 off-site industrial businesses would be impacted.









4.    ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



The alternate release scenario is a leak from an unloading hose connecting the tank car to bulk storage system inside the facility.  An estimated 10 gallons or 100 lbs of TDI is spilled into an undiked area (urban topography) before the flow of product is stopped.  The calculated release rate of an ambient temperature (25 C) using Equation 7-8 from RMP Guidance for OCA is 0.00058 lbs/min.  The corrected release rate at 102? F  ( the highest temperature for the last three years in the Lakeland area obtained from www.wunderground.com) using Equation 3-11 is 0.0021 lbs/min.  The estimated duration of release is 47,619 minutes using Equation 3-5.  The distance to the toxic endpoint was determined using the look up tables in SPI's RMP for TDI Users which is based on the technique described in EPA's RMP Guidance for OCA.  In particular, equation D-1 of the guidance document was used to estimate pool evaporation based upon a vapor pressure correlation published by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).  A Gaussian plume model was used to determine the endpoint distance based upon the evaporation rate. From attachment 7

of the lookup tables for neutrally buoyant plumes, 60 minute releases and urban conditions the endpoint distance is 100 feet (0.02 miles). Based on the calculated endpoint distance of 100 feet (0.02 miles) a release of this magnitude would not impact any off-site residential or industrial receptors.











5.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Carpenter Co. has implemented the RMP Program Level 2 Prevention Program, as described in the RMP regulations, at the facility which include the following elements:  TDI Safety Information, Health Guidelines & Material Safety Data Sheets, Hazard  Review utilizing "What if Checklists", Standard Operating Procedures (TDI Unloading, Transfer Pump Operating and Shutdown, Recirculation Pump Operating & Shutdown, metering Pump Operating & Shutdown, Maintenance Procedures and Pourline Operating Procedures), Employee training, TDI Preventive Maintenance Plan & Checklist, RMP Compliance Audits and TDI Incident Investigation.



      6.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Over the previous five years the Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, has not had any incidents involving TDI.



7.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, utilizes an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to outline the emergency response activities for each class of incident that may occur at the facility.  The facility has made all required notifications to the Polk County LEPC regarding the types of materials stored at the facility and their volumes.  The Lakeland Regional Medical Center, Lakeland Police Department and Lakeland Fire Department have all been given copies of Carpenter Company Lakeland Division's emergency response plan. Carpenter Co. has an Emergency Response Service Agreement with American Compliance Technologies to provide remediation services in the event of a TDI release should occur.  Carpenter Co. maintains a trained Emergency Response Technician Level III Hazwoper Res

ponse team capable of actively controlling a release of TDI. Carpenter Company has signed an agreement with Shaw Environmental Services to provide U.S. facilities with Emergency Response capabilities in the event of a major environmental incident. All Carpenter Co. operations and support personnel have received training in TDI hazard recognition and awareness as well as a thorough review of MSDS sheets.  The facility conducts emergency response and spill response drills on a regular basis.



8.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Carpenter Co., Lakeland Division, operates with an attention to employee awareness and emphas ongoing training of all personnel.  Additionally employees receive Emergency Response Technician Level III Hazwoper training annually.  A TDI unloading checklist has been implemented to ensure equipment is in satisfactory condition prior to use. A mountable drain blocker has been placed next to the tank truck unloading area. The operator must now place this drain blocker above the storm drain next to the truck unloading area prior to each truck unload to prevent possible leakage or spills into the storm drain as a result of leakage from the piping connections.  Continuous improvements are performed as and when technology and processes become available. Carpenter is committed to provide a safe and environmentally responsible working condition for all employees and surrounding community.
